title: Wednesday, 22nd March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

Have to bear with for a moment, cos I'm a bit all over the place

PM11:01am

Even more all over the place than usual

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Distracted most recently by this story https://www.apnews...03de40c5a/Manafort's-plan-to-'greatly-benefit-the-Putin-Government?utm_campaign=SocialFlow&utm_source=Twitter&utm_medium=AP

PM11:02am

Which won't load for me

PM11:02am

Here's a better link

11:02 am
PM11:02am

http://bigstory.ap...faa88108a03de40c5a

PM11:03am

WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump's former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, secretly worked for a Russian billionaire to advance the interests of Russian President Vladimir Putin a decade ago and proposed an ambitious political strategy to undermine anti-Russian opposition across former Soviet republics, The Associated Press has learned. The work appears to contradict assertions by the Trump administration and Manafort himself that he never worked for Russian interests.

Manafort proposed in a confidential strategy plan as early as June 2005 that he would influence politics, business dealings and news coverage inside the United States, Europe and the former Soviet republics to benefit the Putin government, even as U.S.-Russia relations under Republican President George W. Bush grew worse. Manafort pitched the plans to Russian aluminum magnate Oleg Deripaska, a close Putin ally with whom Manafort eventually signed a $10 million annual contract beginning in 2006, according to interviews with several people familiar with payments to Manafort and business records obtained by the AP. Manafort and Deripaska maintained a business relationship until at least 2009, according to one person familiar with the work.

BE11:03am

Time's website works better than AP's: http://time.com/47...r-putin-russia-us/

11:03 am
PM11:03am

This is quite a development -- even in relative Trumpian terms

PM11:03am

It's one thing for healthcare to hit a Congressional log jam

PM11:04am

11:04 am
PM11:04am

It's quite another for all this Russian conspiracy stuff to turn out to be true

BE11:04am

(@blankcanvas: no.)

PM11:05am

Personally, I have alway thought the Russian stuff was nonsense and a distraction

11:05 am
PM11:05am

But who knows...

BE11:05am

PM11:05am

Yeah -- well, thought some might be true -- like encouraging the Russians to hack hiLARy.

11:05 am
PM11:06am

But not beyond that.

BE11:06am

Hm. There's enough circumstantial evidence around for the theme to be taken seriously -- which seems to be what the Feds are doing.

PM11:06am

Markets surely got to start pricing in the chances of 'Trump reflation' turning into full on 'Trump implosion'

11:06 am
PM11:07am

And i guess they are!

BE11:07am

Dunno. Not a clue. I don't think we can speculate reasonably about whether current happenings might lead to impeachment or whatever. For normal rules to apply, we'd have to be living in normal times.

BE11:07am

We're not.

11:07 am

BE11:09am

(Yes, I'm doing that trope again.)

BE11:09am

Yesterday's fall was exclusively sterling. Today's ...... proper.

Though talking about panic and such is very very premature. We've just been stuck in low vol for so long that we've forgotten what 1% moves look like.

11:10 am

11:14 am

Yeah Australia i assume

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Right, I'll dig out the photos from the analyst tour last week.

BE11:17am

Though not immediately, because my computer's being annoying.

BE11:17am

So here's some sellside to talk about Kingfisher still being a bit of a problem

11:17 am
BE11:17am

RBC

BE11:17am

Kingfisher’s FY PBT of £787mn was broadly in line with our forecast of £786mn with the UK and France showing slightly better-than-expected margins but worse LFL sales, and Kingfisher’s outlook statement relatively cautious as expected. The full-year dividend is 10.4p (+3% yoy), a little under our 11p estimate. We don’t expect much change in consensus FY18/19 PBT estimates today given some likely small currency upgrades offset by weaker LFL sales for France.

By region, B&Q LFLs were up 3.5% for the year (vs our estimate of 3.9%) including 2.6pp sales transfer from closed stores, and UK retail profit of £358m was a shade ahead of our estimate of £356mn. Screwfix LFL sales were up +13.8% yoy for the year compared to our +13.6% estimate.

In France, Castorama LFLs decreased -3.0% compared to our -2.3% estimate and Brico Depot LFLs decreased -2.3% compared to our estimate of -1.5%. French retail profit of £353mn was a little ahead of our forecast of £350mn.

Polish LFLs increased 7.5% in line with our +7.5% estimate, while retail profit of £144mn was below our £150mn forecast. Total Other International retail profit of £136mn was below our £141mn estimate.

In terms of guidance Kingfisher still expects to achieve £500mn of net benefits over and above normal course of business by FY20/21, however transformation P&L costs have been raised by £90mn to £310mn, with transformation exceptional costs of £170mn (previously £270mn). KGF is currently c,£10mn ahead of plan on Goods Not for Resale savings. Retail losses from new country development in FY18 are expected to be £15mn as expected, driven by Screwfix Europe. Kingfisher plans to spend £450mn on capex in FY18 (versus our expectation of £500m). The interest charge in FY18 should be c.£5mn versus our c.£8mn forecast and the tax rate 26% versus our 25% estimate.

BE11:17am

Our cautious stance is owing to:

a) the French consumer outlook where our survey work suggests Castorama is lagging Leroy Merlin on various metrics including ecommerce, and we don’t expect Castorama’s online offer to improve until next year;

b) we see a short-term benefit but longer-term threat in the UK from new entrant Bunnings; and

c) as we think execution risk is high this year given the extent of range change in stores.

Kingfisher trades at 14x CY17E P/E, a 5% premium to the sector and we consider a sector rating more appropriate given downside risk to consensus EPS, particularly in the medium term. Our price target is based on DCF analysis using an 8.3% WACC and a terminal growth rate of 1%.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

And Haitong

BE11:18am

This is a mixture of trading (and associated profit) performance and a chance to judge progress on the five year re-structuring programme. The latter is very early stage and the company’s commitment to its full-plan profit uplift of £500m, while re-stated, is in our view not worth very much with limited delivery so far. Obviously that should not detract from the amount of effort that has gone into preparatory work to run the group on a much more centralised basis. However this is very difficult to judge objectively. The narrative presented looks OK to us in the context of previous commentary and we note that the IT platform trial in France appears to have been successful to allow a full roll-out. The magnitude of the execution risk in the current year is highlighted by the increase in the programme cash costs from £77m in 2016/17 to £270m guidance for 2017/18E.

BE11:18am

The French business has come in with quite disappointing sales for the full year as 4Q has clearly continued weak, especially in Castorama where Full Year LFL of -3.0% compared with 9MA of -2.7% and consensus -1.9% (source: KGF) despite weaker comparatives and no noticeable deterioration in Banque de France stats. Clearly KGF is concerned enough over this to be guiding to price investment in the new year, which we would imagine will inhibit any desire to upgrade consensus underlying 2017/18E PBT estimates of c£820m (source KGF).

Daniel Bernard has announced he will retire as Chairman in June 2017 and be replaced by Andy Cosslett – most recently CEO of IHG and a partner of Private Equity firm Advent. We do not know of Mr Cosslett enough to comment. But with this retirement two of the greats of French retailing, Phillipe Tible and Daniel Bernard, have now gone. Mr Cosslett may be better suited to assisting the change process underway at Kingfisher, especially its need to grasp rather than resist the onset of digital. But Kingfisher has now lost some huge retail experience.

We remain sellers on the basis of the challenges posed by the static nature of the UK and French markets, likely impacts of channel switch on market leaders as digital evolves and the sheer scale of the business risk here.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Was there ever a time when Kingfisher wasn't in a five-year restructuring programme?

PM11:18am

hehehe

BE11:19am

They seem to be permanent, and it's always drab stuff like trying to move more own-brand rawlplugs and changing the store cleaners' mops for cheaper mops.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Even for a retailer -- where the whole sector calls the necessary expense of store refits a transformation plan because it sounds like the costs will roll off -- Kingfisher's seems epic and entirely without visible results.

PM11:21am

We should say hello to the new chairman, in passing

PM11:21am

Andy Cosslett

11:21 am
PM11:21am

PM11:21am

PM11:21am

Ferrexpo PLC (FXPO:LSE): Last: 166.00, up 3 (+1.84%), High: 166.70, Low: 156.00, Volume: 2.69m
11:23 am
PM11:23am

http://www.investe...1703220700071500A/

PM11:24am

11:24 am
PM11:24am

PM11:25am

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Actually, the company is saying that

BE11:25am

Yes, they've reinstated it.

BE11:26am

$ 6.6 cents.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

(That isn't how we're supposed to write dollar cents. You know what I mean.)

BE11:27am

Otherwise, operationally okay. And due largely to forces beyond the company's doing the balance sheet is .... well, better. Still not good, but better.

BE11:27am

Here's Barclays.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Ferrexpo released a robust set of results this morning, with EBITDA coming in exactly in line with our forecast and +1% vs. consensus. EPS of 34c however was 10% light of our estimate due to higher tax rate of 18% vs. our assumed 13%. FY revenue was 1% ahead of our estimate on slightly better H2 realized price of $93/t vs. our estimated $86.4/t. C1 cost performance was decent, coming in at $29.7/t in H2, up 16% HoH and 2% below our estimate of $30.4/t. Unit costs were under upward pressure due to higher oil prices, lower production, flat FX and rising domestic inflation. As a result EBITDA rose 37% HoH in H2.

BE11:27am

Cashflow performance strong: it had pre-reported a cash balance of $145m at Dec-16 vs. $44m at Jun-16 (+$101m) net of c.$75m of debt maturities. This was confirmed by the release with $166m FCF in 2H16 vs. $118m in 1H16, benefiting from $24m tax refunds into working capital. As a result net debt declined from $753m at June to $589m as of December, well below our forecast of $639m (consensus $632m). ND/EBITDA fell to 1.6x vs. 2.4x at June 2016 (1H annualized). The balance sheet is much improved with $201m of maturities due in 2017, to be met from cash balances of $145m and our forecast 2017 FCF of $204m. This should leave the company in a position to potentially refinance its bonds over the course of 2017 to address the $263m of maturities falling due in 1H18.

BE11:27am

Surprise dividend reinstatement: on the back of strong cashflow generation FXPO has reinstated dividends at 3.3USc/sh (c.$19m) plus a special dividend of 3.3c/sh equivalent to a total yield of 6.7%. The dividend policy going forward is to pay a base divi of c.$40m (6.6c/sh) per year split equally between an interim and final dividend. This is in-line with dividends paid through 2008-11 (2012-14 was doubled to 13.2c/h including special). On top of the base level, if appropriate, special dividends will be paid from excess cash flows with management targeting a figure around c.$40m per year (6.6c/sh). The prospects for special dividends look demanding relative to our forecast $204m FCF (using $62.5/t CFR 62%) given $201m maturities and $145m cash, but more feasible on spot ($485m FCF).

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Other guidance: cashflow generation in early 2017 is described as “strong”, pellet premiums in 1Q17 have recovered strongly, and development capex spend is expected to increase. Ferrexpo currently has one approved project to increase concentrate output by approximately 1.5mtpa for $50m, which will be incurred in 2017 and 2018. This compares to 2016 capex of $48m (all sustaining).

BE11:28am

The debt's coming down at a fair clip now, though production growth's on a much more gradual slope.

BE11:29am

Two charts .....

11:29 am
BE11:29am

BE11:29am

PM11:29am

Encouraging tho

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Hm. There was a reason people didn't really expect the divi today. I guess it's good that management is confident enough to pay one, though management confidence isn't a great lead indicator with mining companies.

BE11:31am

Have Deutsche Bank as well.

BE11:31am

As production and gross cash were already reported, our focus is on the strong operating performance and successful balance sheet management. Revenue of US$986m increased 4% y/y (DBe US$997m, consensus US$976m). EBITDA was up 20% y/y helped by a 13% reduction in unit costs (cost cutting, lower oil and weaker FX) to US$375m (8% higher than DBe of US$346m, an 11% beat of consensus US$339m). Adjusted EPS of USc30.8 was 7% above DBe but 1% above consensus USc33.2. The relentless focus on debt reduction throughout the year, keeping capex low (down 26% y/y) paid off, in conjunction with the iron ore price recovery – net debt was down 32% y/y to US$589m (consensus US$632m), implying net debt/EBITDA of 1.6x, well on the way to the group’s 1x target. Ferrexpo will resume dividends – it has declared a final base dividend of USc3.3/sh and a special of the same value – a total payout of US$38m, and implied annual yield of 3.2% in total.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

With the hard work of debt reduction largely behind Ferrexpo and cash flow continuing to be strong given current high iron ore prices, management issued an assured outlook statement that (i) net debt/EBITDA would continue to improve in 2017, (ii) it will re-start its concentrator expansion project spending US$50m over this year and next and (iii) it will resume dividend payments with the aim of returning US$40m per annum as a base (USc6.6.sh) total annual dividend. We find this a compelling combination. We forecast a 55% increase in EBITDA to US$582m in 2017, and year end net debt of US$261m, thus well under the 1x gearing target.

undefined
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live etc

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Going at them hard

PM11:33am

Paul Moran round there

RPC Group PLC (RPC:LSE): Last: 889.67, down 21.33 (-2.34%), High: 920.09, Low: 889.33, Volume: 685.08k
11:33 am
PM11:33am

Let them do the talking on this one

PM11:33am

Plastics and stuff, isn't it?

PM11:33am

We believe RPC is a business that is stuck in a structurally weak position, caught between a weakening relative price

position with customers and its labour cost inflation. These trends will worsen we think. It is our view that management is

using a dramatic step-up in acquisitions in the last 12 months (10 deals and a doubling of revenues) and some of the most

aggressive accounting we have seen, to help mask these risks. Given a history of weak free cash flow generation (FCF)

and a levered balance sheet, RPC’s acquisitions require rights issues – and therefore, a compelling equity story. This is

an equity story the sell-side has been very bullish on for many years, perhaps because of underwriting deal fees on offer.

11:33 am
PM11:34am

Multi-year restructuring programmes and acquired synergies have delivered surprisingly little real gains in true net income

or FCF in our view. Innovative management incentives and definitions of returns on capital or return on assets, are

encouraging value destructive deals we think. This can be clearly recognised in the erosion of returns on capital, which on

our analysis, are now well below the cost of capital. After the FY16 accounts, where the raw material tailwind effect failed

to materialise, management sold a significant amount of stock. In H1, this tailwind effect was even weaker on our

analysis. We think consensus assumes the drag from one-off costs disappears and ‘adjusted’ profit matches the true

underlying profit figure.

PM11:34am

We disagree and believe that a strategy to buy industry peers in other segments or geographies,

with modest synergies, doesn’t alleviate structural threats of pricing power and cost inflation, it just reinforces them. We

accept that a rights-issue funded, value destroying roll-up story can continue to report ‘adjusted’ EPS growth for as long

as shareholders are willing to fund it. But should the hitherto supportive appetite for rights issues fade, we think

shareholders will find a structurally challenged, low margin, highly levered, sub cost of capital business trading on c.23x

Mar-18 P/E on our estimates, an undeserved 50% premium to the market. The unusually poor reaction from the market to

a recent large acquisition suggests to us that cracks in the story are beginning to appear. We think it is best to get out

now. Sell.

PM11:34am

I'm looking for other bullish sell side in my inbox

11:34 am

Acacia Mining PLC (ACA:LSE): Last: 469.32, down 7.88 (-1.65%), High: 473.90, Low: 435.10, Volume: 602.74k
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Here's RBC to talk us through Acacia being left on the shelf yet again.

BE11:44am

Plenty of value, plenty of growth, but plenty of questions. The announcement that preliminary talks with Endeavour Mining about a potential merger have come to an end will likely see focus reemerge on the 64% stake held by Barrick Gold. Acacia has traded at a c. 25–35% discount to peers over the past 12 months although this has tightened recently. Our analysis suggests this is due to multiple factors including the majority shareholder overhang, the relative lack of liquidity, and the single-country Tanzania risk. These are all factors that would have been ameliorated had the merger progressed.

Complicating the situation is the recent Tanzanian presidential ban on concentrate exports, which is likely to cause increased share price volatility. The timing of or ability to achieve a resolution is uncertain. We do expect a resolution to be achieved, as the economic rationale for an in-country smelter does not exist; however, the country risk discount is likely to remain elevated for a time, even following resolution.

BE11:44am

North Mara and Kenya to the rescue? The cash burn implications from being unable to process 45% of the effective revenue from Bulyanhulu or 55% from Buzwagi are mitigated by the positive cashflow from North Mara. We do expect a working capital build, however, with c. $450m in liquidity and at current gold prices operations that are near cash breakeven, actual tension on the balance sheet is limited. We highlight that the concentrate ban and the end of the merger talks are likely to overshadow what we continue to see as significant potential upside to the NAV from North Mara and Kenya; we expect more updates on drilling regarding both as the year progresses.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Resuming coverage with Sector Perform rating, but long-term value remains; 450p price target. We expect Acacia to de-rate in the short term and we set a price target of 450p on the shares based on 1.0x P/NAV and 8x P/CF. Over the long term, we expect that Acacia will continue to increase value via development at North Mara and Kenya, and solutions to the structural discount are still likely to be pursued. We look to a further update on the concentrate export situation as the next potential catalyst for the shares.

BE11:44am

And Shore, much briefer.

BE11:44am

We wonder if, following the concentrate ban, Endeavour decided to seek terms improved in its favour (we know we would have). Perhaps they pressed just a bit too hard?

11:45 am
BE11:45am

And Panmure, which of course will soon have an expert onboard on the theme of African value destruction.

PM11:45am

hehehehe

BE11:46am

Acacia Mining and Endeavour Mining confirmed merger talks have now ended with Endeavour claiming an inability to “create adequate value for Endeavour shareholders”, most likely, we believe, given the disappointing ruling from the Tanzanian government on copper-gold concentrate sales. We were positive on the merger and believed a credible London listed Pan-African producer capable of challenging Randgold, would have been established. We make no change to our Hold recommendation today, and expect the shares to be marked lower in early trade.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Target 506p.

11:51 am

Ah, look at this

PM11:52am

There’s been another flurry of publicity for Purplebricks following the posting of photographs and statements online by a blogger whose property was visited by one of the agency’s Local Property Experts.

Dan Stevenson, 26, was pictured and named by London blogger Lorna Hayward after he visited her home and met her two young children, Elsie aged three and Marnie aged 18 months.

PM11:52am

Lorna Hayward posted photographs and statements on Facebook and Instagram, saying her girls “took a real shine to him” and followed the estate agent around the house asking for cuddles and whether he was he staying the night.

She posted on the social media outlets of the parenting group The Motherload which then created the #findDan hashtag - the end result was that over 30,000 people either tweeted, shared or commented on the story.

Now the story has been picked up by a string of national newspapers, the London Evening Standard and several online publications.

We maintain U/P on AMFW in part due to a £25m break-fee which doesn't suggest fundamental strategic rationale drives this deal, in our view.
